subject: Economics
title: Tit for Tat: The Nicest Strategy That Wins
description: Learn Tit for Tat: The Nicest Strategy That Wins in one minute.

hook.text: In 1980, Robert Axelrod asked game theorists to submit strategies for a repeated Prisoner's Dilemma tournament.

buildup.text: Tit for Tat: cooperate on the first move, then copy whatever your opponent did last. Betray me, I betray you.

discovery.text: It beat sophisticated strategies because it was nice (never betrayed first), retaliatory (punished betrayal).

twist.text: Tit for Tat never wins a single game â€” it can only tie or lose against any specific opponent.

climax.text: Tit for Tat teaches that nice guys don't finish last â€” they finish first.

punchline.text: The optimal strategy is simple: start nice, punish betrayal, and always forgive.

quiz.question: Why did Tit for Tat win Axelrod's tournament?
options: It was the most aggressive strategy
It balanced cooperation, retaliation, forgiveness, and clarity â€” never exploiting first but always punishing betrayal
It used random moves to confuse opponents
